title: Will the powers of the government of Myanmar cease to be held by the military before 5 February 2022?
preds: It seems increasingly clear as time runs out for the military to abdicate and no new developments suggest their intention to do so that Feb. 5th with come and go and the military will retain power in Myanmar. Rated the probability as 1% since there must be a non-zero probability that they abdicate.
seems unlikely that military will give up power
Coming up on the 5 Feb date, and no new notice of anything changing. Not shocking, but potentially negative for the people of Myanmar.

US sanctions have been in place on the military leaders of the coup since Feb 11, 2021. Despite this and widespread international condemnation, the coup continues and the military remains firmly in control of all three branches of the government. More than 7,300 protestors of the coup remain imprisoned across the country.  What would have to happen for the government powers to be released from military control? 1) A rightfully elected president would need to be seated / reinstated, 2) article 417 of the Myanmar constitution would need to be recognized (only sitting president may declare a state of emergency), and 3)  the elected president would need to reverse the invocation of article 418 (transfers power of executive, legislative, and judicial branches to Commander-in-Chief of the military).  Given that the rightfully elected president, Aung San Suu Kyi was convicted and sentenced to 4 years in prison (possession of walkie-talkies and COVID 19 protocol violations) on January 10th 2022, and is again being tried for corruption charges it is highly improbable that she will be returned to control of the country in the next 5 days.  The Commander-in-Chief of the military, Gen Min Aung Hlaing - who is currently in power - has stated that the military will form a true democracy on behalf of the people, and that democratic elections will occur once the state of emergency has ended. It is equally as improbable that the state of emergency will be ended, a presidential election will occur, and that the a president other than Kyi will be seated prior to February 5th.  Government control will remain in the military's hands for the foreseeable future.  AlJazzeera: "On the eve of the one-year anniversary of the coup, United Nations’ human rights chief Michelle Bachelet condemned the international response as “ineffectual” saying it lacked “a sense of urgency commensurate to the magnitude of the crisis”." https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/2/1/world-accused-of-sitting-and-watching-as-myanmar-slides-to-war
With only five days left for the military to cease power, I do not see any promising signs that this will be a likely scenario
Just 5 days before the due date of the question and no actions towards the coup have been taken
not likely in such a short time frame
While countries are trying to impose new sanctions on oil and gas, Myanmar's military is still collecting revenues. I don't think the situation will change within the next week and a half.

Closed trials proceed against former members of the pro-democracy party, the leader of the Junta has been offered a way to participate in upcoming ASEAN meetings by the organization's acting chief. It appears that there is little international motivation to pressure the Junta into a course reversal. I think it's nearly certain that the Junta retains the powers of government for the next two weeks.

Myanmar has a long history of military rule; the last interval lasted 22 years  and the “roadmap to democracy” that was offered was widely condemned as a sham which would allow the military to maintain its power.  It seems like the two primary factors which forced the military to at least make concessions to democracy were widespread unrest driven by economic decline  and the personal popularity of Au Sang Suu Kyi. Another contributing factor may have been a desire to strengthen relations with the United States in order to reduce dependence on China.  But Au Sang Suu Kyi’s international popularity has declined significantly as a result of the Rohingya crisis.  Her ability to rally international pressure against the regime is limited, particularly when western democracies are confronting a host of internal problems of their own. The regime has only experienced a small handful of defections by low-ranking officers , which suggests a high degree of internal cohesion. This contrasts greatly with the opposition, which is divided between many different  competing groups.   The most likely scenario that I can see which would threaten military rule would be a) renewed unrest driven by economic decline  combined with b) an internal crisis of leadership caused by a sudden incapacity on the part of Gen. Min Aung Hlaing. Such a crisis could be intensified by divisions of opinion with regards to China on the part of senior officers. Barring something like that, it seems extremely likely the military government will remain in power. 1% because its not impossible and 1% is the lowest it can go, but I think its actually something like .005%
Myanmar has a history of poor governance and now the military is back in control. There is no indication it seriously intends to give up power as soon as Feb 5.

As I understand it, there is little domestic opposition to the military in Myanmar. They have successfully sidelined the country's foremost advocate for democratization and are trying her on a number of charges, some of which she unsurprisingly has been found guilty of already. The international community has responded with sanctions but appears incapable of effecting change in the country by any other means. The current Junta is however technically in place due to a year-long state of emergency declared in the wake of the last election, which is set to expire on Feb. 1st. I think it is unlikely that they abdicate by this deadline since the situation in the country appears to be so unstable, there don't appear to be other possible governing arrangements that would be acceptable to the military leaders, and historically, military leaders in situations such as the one in Myanmar are generally not quick to abdicate or defer to the rule of law.
The military has controlled the country for decades so it's unlikely to lose or give up that power in the next couple weeks.
The Myanmar military leadership will hold its position in power. ASEAN nations' domestic politics and pandemic matters will prevent them from confronting the Myanmar military.
Barring foreign intervention, the military government has not indicated any real desire to cede control.

It is very unlikely. The military looks strong and consolidated. Also, there does not not seems to be a lot of international action regarding this matter. Most states are focused dealing with their own problems such as the Covid-19 pandemic, high inflation rates and supply shortages.

Highly unlikely. After seizing power they have consolidated their position inside the country and given the current state of international affairs (pandemic and related troubles) there is little appetite for outside pressure.

Highly unlikely that the military junta will cede control of Myanmar in the short term. The Junta's decision to even commit the coup, given its already privileged position, is evidence enough that the military has no visions of ceding control. ASEAN, arguably the only international body with some power in Myanmar, is splintered on the issue and concerned with the pandemic; not to mention that Myanmar has always treated ASEAN disrespectfully, second-rate compared to its relationship with China. I'd be more interested to see if Myanmar is expelled from ASEAN, although I doubt that too given Myanmar's boosters in the grouping. I imagine once the West starts getting even more distracted by domestic politics, i.e. the heat of mid-terms in the US or France's election, the Junta will be brought into the legitimate fold in ASEAN + other forums dominated by East Asian interests.
The military leadership has taken few steps in this direction and seems to be consolidating power and extending the one year state of emergency.

I would say it is not unlikely considering they keep giving Aung San Suu Kyi, an advocate for democracy, more charges to end her public life. Further, there have been movement or plan towards ceasing their powers (if there has been, it has not been public).

They would have less than a month to do it now.
The Cambodian PM has now made an official visit (search Hun Sen Myanmar) which could suggest endorsement of the current regime (though it could be talking to them about a pathway to relinquishing power).

* How long 'til deadline?: 30 days (not very long for anything to happen in)
* How often do coup perps voluntarily relinquish power anywhere?: Fairly rarely, and usually quite gradually when they do.
* Is there any sign anyone wants to / can oust the military by force or public rising?: Apparently some attempts, but they seem to get put down.
* More or less than 50%? Less
* More or less than 25%? Less
* More or less than 10%? Less
* More or less than 5%? Less
* More or less than 0%? 0% is extreme. 1%.
The military will not give up any of its powers in the short term and not until forced or pressed through international negotiations.
There is no better option than the position the junta is in now.

Knowledge I think is a fair exchange for a poor Brier.

Myanmar's military controlled the country's legislative, executive and judiciary power until 2011, after a military coup in 1962. The military's influence over politics and economy remained significant also after the 2011 opening (25% of seats in the parliament reserved for the military, military conglomerates). Hence, the period of democratic rule in Myanmar is significantly shorter in the country's history since independence from Britain in 1948, providing the military with the capabilities to rule the country. Also other parameters of military rule remain the same, mostly importantly, regional powers continue the traditional policy of non-interference and are unlikely to apply sanctions or other restrictive measures against the junta, shielding the latter from EU/US sanctions. In addition, the (armed) opposition to the military, the Ethnic Armed Organizations (EAO) and newly established Popular Defense Units (PDU) do not have much in common apart from their opposition to the military and frictions over the course of action already emerged; EAOs may also use the current crisis to negotiate with the military. A difference to the pre-2011 period is the population's ability to stage a blockade of the large parts of the economy through the use of social media. However, the military's control of communication networks is likely to disrupt these networks. The impact of the blockage is also more likely to harm the population than the junta itself.

The Myanmar junta protect the law. The law is paramount to their legitimacy, so likely there will be an election after the year of emergency (rebels will not be allowed to partake, ethnic militias - likely will be allowed), However! Setting up an election would take time. So likely as of 5 FEB the power will still be in the hands of the military with election underway. But by January there will be a formal civilian government. Even if it will consist of 90% Tamado.
The support, more or less implicit from nearby gouvernments is too strong. The current goverment may fall but it’will take a real civil war I ´m afraid

Dividing the probability by 3. It seems it's heading more towards civil war. So Myanmar would need a military defeat for this to happen. I'm happy to have got it very wrong in this question. You can't improve without making mistakes.  In particular, my learning is that if the military refuse to yield against people power, the military can usually hold on but the state simply slips into a failed state / civil war situation. So it will then come down to whether the military leaders value their personal power of a little bit above the overwhelming needs of the state and people they hope to lead. And the answer in many cases is no. So going forward, in developing a better model for these types of qs, Q1 is, will the military shoot? In Egypt, they didn't. In Syria they did. In Venezualla they did. In Myanmar they did. In Tunisia they didn't. Etc. If yes, the regime will fall. Q2 is, will the tyrants in power value their personal power above that of the overwhelming interests of the state and people they seek to lead? If yes, the regime will compromise and / or fall. If no, the state becomes a failed state and / or enters a civil war. But this will then become long and drawn out. Q3 is, if the regime chooses failed state / civil war, will there be outside intervention? If they have a major backer or there is no significant interest from the West (Mayanmar) then no.  I suppose there is also another end state to consider: the regime succeeds in crushing the demonstrations and restores fear based deterrence. So my mistake was that I did not see how this could end while the people still were protesting. Now I can: civil war / failed state. What I at least have achieved by getting this wrong is identifying all the end states: the army does not fire and the regime falls; the regime has some heart and compromises or falls; civil war / failed state; and external intervention. Now, all I need to do is build a model that can map the current state of domestic and geo-politics to the final end state. Which is much easier to do when one is aware of all the possible end states. And thinking about it more, the model is simply this. Forecast the probability of each of these end states and then ensure the sum of these probabilities add to 100%. And the answer will follow. @cafebedouin, @michal_dubrawski [thanks michal for typo correction]. Particularly keen on your thoughts given our history of discussing this. But also keen on the views of anybody else.

This question effectively asks, "will the military end the state of emergency early and hand over power to a civilian government?" Considering their proxy party was roundly defeated in the last (reportedly fair) election, this seems unlikely.

The predecessors of this group stayed in power for decades. They receded to the background with Suu Kyi, retaining power. I doubt they will relinquish any power by Feb 2022. Internal divisions.. a "falling out among thieves" as it were, becomes a different game.. but even then, a handover to a non military figure or figurehead seems unlikely to me.

No change in my forecast, but an interesting article in the WaPo today with an important analytical nugget, in my view at least, from an Australian academic quoted on what we should be looking at to see whether to change our forecast based on an inside view: whether a split emerges in the military.[1]  I was thinking today about what would cause me to reevaluate my forecast on this question, and it had never occurred to me to think about a schism inside the military.  My reevaluations have been focused almost exclusively on the outside story via international pressure from the West and regional neighbors. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/myanmar-military-dead-protesters-family/2021/03/27/8818cf5a-8d24-11eb-a33e-da28941cb9ac_story.html

I find it unlikely that Myanmar (formerly Burma) will cease to be held by military forces before 5 Feb 2022. There has, thus far, been little international pressure on the now rogue nation. Myanmar has been embroiled in scandals, including their treatment of the Rohingya Muslims within their country, something that Ms Suu Kyi had to appear before the ICC for in 2019. These things may have provided an opening for the military coup that took place.  That said, the military has always held a firm grip on power within the country, retaining strong control, especially over the legislative branch of their government. The judiciary is not much different. However, there is a possibility given international force that they might relent. That however, is extremely unlikely. China, at the moment, seems to be backing the regimes play for their own reasons, but at present those are unknown. The belt and road initiative that China has been pursuing for many years has generated a lot of influence within the region and beyond so they will likely want to keep these "small struggles" as insignificant as possible. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_Myanmar

Most likely no, but the chance of China reacting strongly to an international reaction is likely low too because China actually had close ties to the democratic government in Myanmar, and the military government is significantly more wary of foreign influence.

I feel that internal resistance combined with external pressure will force the military to hold elections this year. As the mechanisms are established this could happen quite quickly once pending legal actions are resolved.
We tried that once and it didn't work out, probably more repression ahead.

Believe it is possible that the military will be forced to concede some power before Feb 2022 if protesters manage to sustain pressure and international community exert some influence to force the military to concede to some transfer of power.

With international pressure, possible sanctions, and, of course possible protests and pro-democracy organization within the country, it is conceivable that the military cedes some powers. However, this is very unlikely given the strength of the military and its history leading the country.

U.N. says "the world is watching", whatever that means. The first protester has died, 450 are reportedly detained and arrested.
International pressure will be kept up, and the announcement of new elections is a sign of awareness of their own weakness of the military. It's a riddle to me, how the military will, from a tactical/strategical standpoint, deal with the current government: if the "powers" will cease to be held, they will be elected all over again, with a stronger majority than before. If they are criminally charged for whatever flimsy reason, the people of Myanmar will get even more enraged, and who should effectively run for office? The CCP?

Junta pledges to hold elections within a year. So this may come down to timing of when elections are held and when the new government takes office.  https://thehill.com/policy/international/538962-myanmar-military-our-objective-is-to-hold-an-election-and-hand-power-to
Elections were held in November with new government taking office february 1.
I think they lack incentive at the time being.
What are the odds that various government officials ordered the military services to declare a state of emergency secondary to conflict in the region?

Okay, I'm going to go out on a limb here with 60%. This is not an area I have looked into and this will probably hurt my Brier. Safest to just stay out. But who cares about my Brier? My forecast is my forecast. I know from previous discussions with @cafebedouin that the average probability for these types of questions is about 5%. However, this is not a normal case. There is one big big factor at play here that does not seem to have been appreciated in the above forecasts that substantially boosts the likelihood of the coup ultimately failing: that the coup replaced a democratic regime rather than simply replacing one autocracy with another. Further, this coup goes against a democratic result that had been announced and certified. Normally coups include faking election results and stealing elections before the results are announced.  These matter. Stealing an election is much easier to do before the results have been announced and validated because that's not a genie that can be put easily back into a bottle. And the people who had to fight to bring down a regime will be vastly more motived to fight autocracy after they have already succeeded  just a few years ago and the moral of the police force and the army to fight for autocracy will be vastly less.  And indeed there are signs of the police refusing to fight for the regime.  It really comes down to a taste of freedom. Once people have had that taste, it becomes much harder to ever take it away, at least by force alone. And Feb 22 gives a good amount of time for the regime to fall.  The counter argument is I haven't done a full analysis of these kinds of problems yet so there is a high risk that @cafebedouin's flat 5% could still be right.  But given the size of the political forces the coup leaders are going against, I think the probability is more like 90%. However, @cafebedouin's ideas are also convincing. 60% represents a fair balance. In this case, though, the 60% is literally weight I give my forecast * 90% + weight I give @cafebedouin's ideas * forecast. Usually, I try to prod further and see if I end up moving entirely to my version or the counter argument, but I can't do that so this is the best I can do.  I know my absolute brier therefore must be poor, because @cafebedouin's advice and my forecast are mutually incompatible. But with most people going for the low %ages, my relative brier can still do very well if my forecast is decent. But more persuasive to me is that this is my forecasting truth, and that matters more to me than the high likilihood my Brier will go down as a result of me answering questions outside of my comfort zone.

The November 2020 election in Myanmar provided a landslide victory for the party of Aung San Suu Kyi, the National League for Democracy (NLD)that wrested control from the military's proxy Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP).
Citing voter fraud, the military mounted a coup that deposed the government and detained Aung San Suu Kyi and charged her with possessing illegally imported walkie-talkies.
The electoral commission has derided the accusations of election fraud.
Reported opinion is that the coup was conducted due to the USPD’S loss of seats and therefore power in the Parliament.
This loss of power would deprive, it is said, the senior military general, Min Aung Hlaing’s personal ambition of becoming the President, where he had been raising his public profile by posting his activities on Facebook (later taken down by the site).
Campaign groups have also suggested the threat to the General’s wealth and his family’s income stream as being an ulterior motive to regain power. He could also face accusations of war crimes against Rohingya Muslims and is the subject of cases pending in international courts that could seek his arrest. 
In the past foreign opinion and sanctions would appear to have little effect on the military government and this has been accentuated by the actions of Russia and China who have blocked the UN Security Council statement concerning the coup. Also, the near neighbours of Cambodia, Thailand and the Philippines have declared it to be an ‘internal matter.’
The Military may have considered the recent visit by China’s foreign minister Wang Yi, who praised the Myanmar Generals and support for the ‘deserved role in the course of national transformation and development.’  to have provided a nod of acceptance of the coup.
The Chinese news agency, Xinhua have described the coup as a ‘major cabinet reshuffle’ and by a refusal, by China to condemn it, may have given the Military extra confidence.
History shows that the military will not necessarily step down in one year, given that it took twenty years from the 1990 election to complete a promised transition to democracy. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-55902070  https://edition.cnn.com/2021/02/06/asia/myanmar-coup-what-led-to-it-intl-hnk/index.html  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/2/1/who-is-min-aung-hlaing  https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Myanmar-Coup/Fear-and-ambition-in-Myanmar-Why-top-general-triggered-the-coup  https://thediplomat.com/2021/02/what-the-myanmar-coup-means-for-china/  https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/05/world/asia/myanmar-coup-china-united-states.html  https://www.businessinsider.com/china-russia-block-un-security-council-condemn-myanmar-coup-2021-2  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/feb/01/myanmar-coup-us-and-china-divided-in-response-to-army-takeover-aung-san-suu-kyi  https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/02/03/asia-pacific/myanmar-army-election/  https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/explained-myanmar-generals-are-back-in-charge-but-for-how-long/articleshow/80648652.cms

No past evidence that the Myanmar military is eager to surrender the power that it has seized.

Reducing my forecast because the military is responding to protests with more repressive measures. This reaction signals to me that the military is digging in for the long haul and the chance of a transfer of power is very low. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/12/world/asia/myanmar-military-protest.html

Consistent with the excellent analysis of @hoosier2020 and @Econja2018, I'd find it highly unlikely that the military government will hand over power after one year of its self-declared state of emergency.  Looking at the history of military rule in Burma, the shortest interval of military rule seems to be two years and that was in the 1960s.[1]  Since then, the military junta of the day has regularly extended its states of emergency for years of military dictatorship.  As others have pointed out, Chinese support for the military government bilaterally and in international fora give the military regime cover at the UN.    Japan has also been notable for its silence after the coup, highlighting its close ties with Burma regardless of the regime, which gives further space to the military to prolong its rule.[2]  Additionally, South Korea, Singapore, and Thailand have invested heavily in Burma.[3]  With all of those investments essentially stranded, those companies will be loath to alienate the military rulers.  They will not be shy about lobbying their national governments to protect their interests in Burma, lessening chances of regional pressure to end the military regime. Nobel Prize Winner Aung Sang Suu Kyi's shocking and seemingly heartfelt defense of genocide against the Rohinyga people has also undercut support by her traditional allies in the Western NGO and human rights community.[4]  Washington, London, Ottawa, and Canberra will continue to issue statements of concern, urging the resumption of civilian government.  Nonetheless, leaders in these countries will have even less pressure from human rights groups and NGOs to engage  meaningful sanctions or other levers of power to force the Burmese military government back to barracks. [2] https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/Myanmar-Coup/Japan-slow-to-join-global-chorus-denouncing-Myanmar-coup
[3] https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/05/world/asia/myanmar-coup-china-united-states.html
[4] https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-pacific-11685977
No, I don't see a power shift anytime soon.

It would not be convenient for them to give up control after taking it. China has downplayed the issue, so I'm guessing they've also decided that the military is not going to lose power anytime soon. And as other commenters have noted, the military has historically ruled the country for many years.

The military maintained its grip on power for years, until it relinquished some control in 2011, despite pro-democracy protests. China has blocked a UNSC resolution condemning the coup (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-55913947) and is likely to continue providing economic support to Myanmar strengthening the position of the military. If the military turns over power before its one year declared emergency ends it would suffer a loss of legitimacy which is an outcome it is unlikely to accept. The factors that would increase the chance of the military handing over power are international sanctions that cripple the economy or hurt the generals' personal finances, pressure from China, or protests and strikes of a massive scale that make governing nearly impossible. All of this causes me to believe the chance of the military handing over power is low but not impossible.

Myanmar have close ties with China.

Myanmar has a recent history of military rule. The civilian interlude was the aberration.
Once in power, people tend to like it and stay as long as they can, or longer.  The Myanmar military are shining examples of this.  Stay tuned.
